DataElement.preferredName: Local-Regional Urothelial Neoplasm Additional Surgical Procedure Anatomic Site
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to represent the anatomic site of the body on which additional surgery for a new locoregional urothelial tumor event was performed

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Local-Regional Urothelial Neoplasm Additional Surgical Procedure Anatomic Site
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Affecting only a restricted part or area of the body.__Transitional epithelium lining the renal pelvis, bladder, ureter, and part of the urethra._(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth._Derived as a result of a primary condition; not direct or immediate; of second rank or importance or value.__Added; extra; further._A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery._Named locations of or within the body.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Local-Regional; affecting only a restricted part or area of the body.:Transitional epithelium lining the renal pelvis, bladder, ureter, and part of the urethra.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to both a local and regional area of the body.
Transitional epithelium lining the renal pelvis, bladder, ureter, and part of the urethra.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Added; extra. (from American Heritage Dictionary):A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.:Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.
Named locations of or within the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the bladder epithelium.  Approximately 90% of the bladder carcinomas are transitional cell carcinomas.  The remainder are squamous cell carcinomas, adenocarcinomas and small cell neuroendocrine carcinomas._Named locations of, or within, the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The tube carrying urine from the bladder to outside of the body.

Concepts.definition: The tube carrying urine from the bladder to outside of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A distensible musculomembranous organ serving as a receptacle for fluid, as the gallbladder.

Concepts.definition: The distensible sac-like organ that functions as a reservoir of urine, collecting from the kidneys and eliminating via the urethra.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The area at the center of the kidney. Urine collects here and is funneled into the ureter, the tube that connects the kidney to the bladder.

Concepts.definition: The funnel-shaped proximal portion of the ureter located within the kidney into which urine is secreted, from the collecting duct system of the kidney.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The thick-walled tube that carries urine from each kidney to the bladder.

Concepts.definition: The thick-walled tube that carries urine from each kidney to the bladder.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the bladder epithelium.  Approximately 90% of the bladder carcinomas are transitional cell carcinomas.  The remainder are squamous cell carcinomas, adenocarcinomas and small cell neuroendocrine carcinomas.:Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the bladder epithelium.  Approximately 90% of the bladder carcinomas are transitional cell carcinomas.  The remainder are squamous cell carcinomas, adenocarcinomas and small cell neuroendocrine carcinomas.
Named locations of or within the body.
